FUJI to develop a system to prevent abandoned cars | Chubu Economic Newspaper
FUJI (headquarters: Chiryu City), which manufactures and sells electronic parts and machine tools, has started developing a system to prevent children from being left behind in cars.
The system is equipped with a human sensor in the car, which detects human movement. When the human sensor detects movement, it sends a notification to the phone or chat.
Currently, the company is conducting a proof-of-concept test of its own shuttle vehicles.
While there are also unfortunate accidents caused by leaving them behind, we will protect the safety of children and pets.
Currently, two shuttle buses operated by the company are being tested for the after-school English conversation school “teracoya THANK” for children in Chigasaki City.
The human sensors that detect human movement from the temperature difference between people and their surroundings are installed in three locations on the ceiling of the car.
If the driver turns off the vehicle and closes the door, and after a certain period of time, the system will detect the movement of people and automatically send a warning notification.
By linking the status and information of the encounters and the towers, it can prevent misidentification as much as possible.
The warning notification was sent through Clout.
In addition to calling the registered number, it will be displayed on the chat of the smartphone and the smartphone.
Register multiple attendees and be mindful of not missing any.
The proof-of-concept experiment will continue until the end of February.
According to Katsuhiko Shigeyoshi, the chief of the 2nd Section of the Innovation Promotion Department, "during the experiment, other peripheral issues besides the system were also found."
He said that he was able to focus on driving because he was able to create an environment that allowed him to do so, and that he was able to address a wide range of issues related to schoolhouses.
He is putting all his strength into spreading the solution.
The development of the anti-abandonment system was triggered by a series of abandonment accidents in the country.
From employees with young children, proposals were made on what can be done to ensure the safety of children.

After deciding to develop the product, the team utilized their knowledge of IoT (Internet of Things) and information management using sensors, which they had cultivated through their work in FA (factory automation) related businesses.
FUJI’s anti-theft system is easy to use and affordable.
The sensor is installed by hanging it from the ceiling.
Since it is easy to attach to a shuttle bus, the company decided to introduce it and aim for popularization.
In the future, we will also seek cooperation from kindergartens and nursery schools, and consider productization.

[Opinion] Komatsu City is making and distributing the "Entainment Note" to residents who wish to receive it.

"When we published 'Okyami Hantte Fukku' (a guide to procedures and writing a list of assets and family tree when a family member dies) last year, many people came to pick up a copy for themselves," he said.
There are also seminars on how to write an enthinque note and how to organize your life before you die, and it seems that "end of life" has become a common term among the citizens.
The notebook in Echizen Town is 35 pages.

Chapter 5 starts with a review of your life, and then you write down your current health status, your financial situation, your future care needs, your wishes for end-of-life care and hospice, your wishes for funeral and burial.
There are also sections for things you want to do in the rest of your life and messages to people you hold dear.
It was hard to write that there were 35 heads, and I didn't need to bury all the heads.
She asked those around her what they would like to be remembered for.
The most important thing is to make the purpose clear.
Bookstores have a variety of notebooks that are suitable for different purposes, and it is easy to start writing from the place where you can write.
It was in 2009 that the word "end-of-life" was coined to describe the job search.
Two years later, in 2011, the Great East Japan Earthquake occurred.
Many people have come to realize that death can come suddenly, and there are more people who are preparing for their own end and the end of their loved ones.
It has been more than 10 years since then.
The new coronavirus pandemic that has swept the world has not yet subsided.
As a result of the Russian invasion of Ukraine, prices have risen, and this winter electricity prices have skyrocketed.
On the other hand, wages are still not keeping up with the current high cost of living, and many people are struggling to make ends meet.
On the other hand, funeral expenses and nursing expenses that were once shared by relatives, as well as the management of graves, are now rare in a time when single children are not uncommon.
Furthermore, the life expectancy has been extended significantly in the past, and the risk of dementia and need for care increases as people get older.
It is necessary to bear in mind that the background of the end-of-life care that has become established is also the rise of social unease.
Anyway, nobody wants to put Hartner and his son through too much.
The phrase "to die as yourself" is also a key word that is popular among Enthink Note users, and it is not appropriate to become too self-conscious.
It is not good to secretly write down hopes and wishes, and it is better to consult with family members and prepare for that time calmly.

The elementary school principal said, "Children were confused when they suddenly stopped wearing masks. After we decided that wearing masks was optional, more children took them off, and it was a natural flow."

Chorus, physical education and club activities will be conducted without masks in principle.

Graduation ceremonies at elementary, junior high, and high schools, as well as universities, will be held during the 2022 academic year, provided that measures are taken to improve ventilation, and that graduates, faculty, and students in attendance wear masks as a basic rule.

Hotel Helyno received subsidies for inappropriate reasons, and the prefecture and the city’s accommodation support project has already been fully returned | Iwanichi Online, Iwate Nippo

Iwate Prefecture and Ichinoseki City announced on the 10th that the subsidy for the cancellation of the accommodation fees of travelers was improperly used for about a year from October 2021 at the Hotel Geralino Ichinoseki (in Yamemori, Ichinoseki City).
When guests stay at the hotel, they are not eligible for the discount, but the staff member will lend their name to the guest to make them eligible for the discount.
Many employees also confirmed that they used the lodging for purposes other than the business objective of "promoting tourism."
Including the self-investigation by the prefecture, the city, and the hotels, the total amount of the improper use was 7.231 million yen, which was returned on June 6.

The irregularities in the subsidies were in the Iwate Tourism Accommodation Support Project, which was implemented by the prefecture to deal with the spread of the novel coronavirus, and the Ichi no Seki Accommodation Support Project, which was implemented by the city to deal with the spread of the novel coronavirus.

The period is from October 18, 2021 to October 10, 2022 (excluding Ichinoseki accommodation support vouchers on September 30, 2022), and as a result of the survey, inappropriate use that is excluded from the application of the voucher discount, such as use outside the target area or vaccination, was 95 cases for 587

While the prefectural government was proceeding with the calculation procedure, it was confirmed that the user of the accommodation discount and the person in charge of reception at the hotel were the same person.
The prefecture's detailed investigation revealed inappropriate use, and the city also confirmed the facts after obtaining such information.
The city's business has already ended, and the registration of the prefectural business was deleted on December 2 last year.

According to the report, Toshiaki Tsuchiya, representative director of the hotel, said, “We are sorry for causing trouble to everyone in the region, the prefecture, the city, and many people. We are deeply reflecting on this. The hotel is for everyone in the region, and we want to start again from scratch and work hard to regain trust.” The hotel plans to hold a training session for all employees to re-emphasize compliance.

"We are very sorry for this incident," said Chiba Koujin, the chief of the tourism and promotion section of the prefecture. "We will encourage people to follow the rules and establish a sense of compliance, and we hope to encourage proper use in line with the purpose of our business."
Mayor Sato said, "I am truly sorry that there was improper use of the accommodation facilities in the city."

Introduction to the pioneers of plant research, including the collection materials from Mt. Yakushi. Exhibition at Iwate General Cultural Property Center [Hachimantai]|Iwanichi Online Iwate Nippo Co., Ltd.

An exhibition titled "People who introduced the flowers of Mt. Zaō, a treasure trove of alpine plants" and "A brief history of the research on plants in Mt. Zaō" was held at the Zaō Municipal Cultural Property Center in Ota-machi, Hakuba-machi, until December 12.
The exhibition features 124 precious specimens and materials collected by the ancestors, and introduces the footprints of the ancestors who contributed to the research on plants in Mt. Fuji.

The research on plants in Mt. Zaō began with Carl Johann Maximowicz (1827-1891), a Russian botanist who came to Japan in the late Edo period, and Sukegawa Chōnosuke (1842-1925), who was born in Shiwa and collected plants under Maximowicz’s guidance.
Maximo, who was not allowed to walk freely in the country, asked Suzuka to collect it, and continued his research for three years with Yokohama and Nagasaki as his bases.

Suzuran continued to support the research after Machisimoe's return to Japan, and contributed to the publication of the Himalayan endemic species "Himecosakura," "Nanffutouu-chiso," and "Miyamayamafukishouma."

After that, Makino Fujiairo (1862-1957), a modern botanist, published Nannufloros, Kohazanocox, Nannufinnussana, and Katouhakohage, which were discovered and named by himself based on the collection of local researchers in 1903 (Meiji 36) and 1905 (Meiji 38), respectively.
From the exhibit materials, it can be seen that many researchers have revealed the precious alpine plants.

The article also introduces the people who accompanied the survey on the preservation of natural monuments in 1942, such as Sumihiro Sugimura, who was a botanist and was conducting research at Fukagawa Elementary School, and Taroh Tamagawa, who was a curator at the Yama-kaku Museum in Ota City and also participated in the publication of "Plants of Mt. Fuji."

"The botanist of the center, Yoshida, said that the name of each plant of Mt. Takao is the result of a lot of research and the connection between people. It is possible to feel the connection between researchers from local areas and all over the country," said the botanist of the center, Yoshida.

The exhibition is divided into four chapters. Chapter 1 introduces the faith and history of Mt. Hakusan. Chapter 2 is based on the research of Heinrich Eduard Suess (1831-1914), a geologist of the Tui people who laid the foundation of Japanese geology, and also explains the characteristics of Mt. Hakusan from the perspective of geology.

Agreement on reintroduction of renewable energy and goals. Amami Airport. The 2nd Carbon Decarbonization Promotion Meeting | Society & Economy | Nankai Daily News
Promotion meeting to reduce carbonization of Amami Airport = On September 9, Kagiri, Amami City

With the aim of reducing greenhouse gas emissions at Amami Airport (Kasari-cho, Amami City), the Amami Airport Decarbonization Promotion Council (Chairman: Takashi Ando, Chief of Construction Department, Okinawa Prefectural Office of Amami-Oshima, 13 members) held its second meeting on September 9.
All members attended, including online.
They exchanged opinions on setting carbon reduction targets and introducing renewable energy sources, mainly solar power generation.

The Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism has set a total goal of reducing greenhouse gas emissions at airports by 46% or more in 30 years (compared to fiscal 2013) to achieve the "carbon neutrality" by 2050.
In response, the council held its first meeting in November last year, aiming to establish a plan ahead of other airports on the other six islands in the prefecture.
The second meeting was closed to the public, except for the beginning, as the first one.
According to the interview with the president of the company after the event, the purpose of the meeting was to confirm the greenhouse gas emissions of the airport.
The two sides are working towards setting targets and introducing renewable energy, in line with the guidelines of the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry.
According to the distribution material, the CO2 emissions of the airport facilities and vehicles in the same year were 1,476 tons (excluding aircraft).

Among these, the emission of lighting and air conditioning in the airport terminal building and 7 other facilities accounted for about 90%, followed by airport lighting 84 tons and airport vehicles 71 tons.
The council is discussing reducing the emissions of these facilities and vehicles.
Ando said, "We have reached a point of agreement among the committee members, and we would like to make a solid preparation for the interim report."
In the future, the third meeting will hear the interim report and the fourth meeting will hear the final report, and then the plan will be formulated.
The flow of people to the island is increasing. Sakasama Real Estate opens Okinawa-Torishima branch office. People who want to rent a house are welcome. |Society & Economy |Minami-kai News
The talk session was titled "Understanding Sakasama Real Estate" and was held on August 8 at the opening ceremony of the famous town of Shikama.

Okinawa Prefectural Bureau of Okiura: On August 8, the opening ceremony of the Okinawa branch of "Sakasama Real Estate," a real estate website that seeks landlords for people who want to use empty houses or shops for their projects, was held at the community center "entaku" in Okiura Town, Okinawa.
Through the talk session, the company explained the outline of the service.

Tsukimino Hama (Teshima, Nagasaki Prefecture), the representative director in charge of the branch office, said, "We will try to carry out this project on Okinotorishima, and if we can create a movement and flow that invites people to the island, it will be great."

Sakasama Real Estate works in reverse of the usual real estate procedures, by revealing the information of the people who want to borrow, and then contacting the lenders and reaching an agreement between the two parties.
As a demonstration experiment to discover potential vacant houses and build relationships through vacant houses, On-Co Co., Ltd. (headquarters in Mie Prefecture) started Sahi in June 2020.
This is the ninth branch office to be opened in Kyushu.
This is the first time in the country.
About 20 people, including staff from On-Co and Tsukino-ha, town hall employees from Wakaba and Shiminmachi, and local residents, participated in the event.

"As the movement to invite people from outside the island is becoming more active, I thought that we could make use of vacant houses and vacant shops to make the town and the island more lively," said Okubo, explaining the background of the establishment of the branch office.
"There are people who have property on the island and people who want to do something about it, and we want to help them make progress," he said.

On-Co representative, Takashi Mizutani, pointed out that it is necessary to discuss what to pay attention to when operating the facility, such as "whether to take care of each vacant house, whether to ask people who want to help the local area, and what to use as a reference."
"The more people connect with each other, the more information will be gathered," he said, urging the islanders to participate in the talks and cooperate in providing information.
